Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (summary process.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (summary process and related landlord-tenant provisions)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (summary process.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Boston Housing Court under Massachusetts law because the Premises are located in Roxbury (Suffolk County) and the action arises from a landlord-tenant relationship and an alleged breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (landlord and te.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (landlord and tenant statutes)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (landlord and te.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord implicitly warrants that the tenant shall have quiet enjoyment of the leased premises and that the premises will be fit for residential use; the landlord must not substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, nor permit conditions that deprive a tenant of substantial use and enjoyment after notice and a reasonable opportunity to cure.

105 CMR 410.000 (Minimum Standards of Fi.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord implicitly warrants that the tenant shall have quiet enjoyment of the leased premises and that the premises will be fit for residential use; the landlord must not substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, nor permit conditions that deprive a tenant of substantial use and enjoyment after notice and a reasonable opportunity to cure.

Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.raw_text: Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.proposition: A landlord’s failure to repair conditions that materially interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises after notice may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and entitle the tenant to damages and equitable relief.

Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp..raw_text: Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp., 439 F.2d 477 (D.C. Cir. 1971)
Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp..proposition: A landlord’s failure to repair conditions that materially interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises after notice may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and entitle the tenant to damages and equitable relief.
Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp..case_name: Sarah B. Kline v. 1500 Massachusetts Avenue Apartment Corporation
Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp..support_reasoning: The case is a tort/security case about a landlord’s duty to protect tenants from foreseeable criminal acts in common areas, not about failure to repair conditions in a leased unit or breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The majority grounds liability in a duty of reasonable care and an implied contractual obligation to maintain a level of security, and speaks of damages in negligence, not quiet-enjoyment-based remedies. Thus, it does not establish that failure to repair materially interfering conditions after notice constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or supports equitable relief on that theory.
Kline v. 1500 Mass. Ave. Apartment Corp..relevant_excerpt:
“Upon consideration of all pertinent factors, we find that there is a duty of protection owed by the landlord to the tenant in an urban multiple unit apartment dwelling.…

Secondly, on the rationale of this court in Levine v. Katz, Kendall v. Gore Properties, and Javins v. First National Realty Corporation, supra, there is implied in the contract between landlord and tenant an obligation on the landlord to provide those protective measures which are within his reasonable capacity.… The appellant tenant was entitled to performance by the landlord measured by this standard of protection whether the landlord’s obligation be viewed as grounded in contract or in tort.”
